SystemOutput:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Follow-up of chronic problems. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Mr. Brian Smith is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow- up of his Chronic problems. It has been a little while since I have seen the patient. The patient reports he just feels out of sorts lately. He does not know if it is the change in the seasons or if he is getting a cold. He notes he has been doing a lot of projects around the house and some construction on his own. He reports he is just so tired and fatigued that he feels lightheaded. This has been going on for approximately 5 weeks. He denies any fevers, chills, or shortness of breath. Mr. Smith does note he feels bloated every once in a while. He is taking his medications and his Lasix. Regarding his diet, it has been slightly off lately as they began construction on our kitchen over labor day weekend and it was hard to cook or prepare meals so we ate out a lot, and not always the best food out. It kind of reeked havoc at that time. He states he is watching his diet. He endorses weight gain and unintentional weight gain, but denies any hematochezia, vomiting, or diarrhea. Regarding chest pain, he notes it seems to go away after about an hour after he first feels it. He also endorses slight cramps in his chest that can be caused by fluid in his lungs. He Endorses cough and mild dyspnea on exertion. 

VITALS

 All vital signs are within the normal limits. Blood pressure: 120/80 mmHg Heart rate: within normal limits Oxygenation: Within normal limits 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 CV: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur, which we have heard in the past. RESPIRATORY: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally, 1+ pitting edema, jugular venous distention, and lower extremity edema. 

RESULTS

 Chest x-ray, 4 months ago, shows decreased ejection fraction of 45%. Echocardiogram demonstrates leaky valve and mitral regurgitation. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 • Congestive Heart failure. • Medical Reasoning: I believe he is retaining fluid. • Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the importance of home renovations and that his home renovations should be complete by then. • Additional Testing: We will order a repeat echococardogram. • medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 He will continue to follow-up with me after he gets his test results.

She describes the pain as being right in the middle of her knee. She places the pain mostly in the medial aspect of the knee and states it is mostly tender there. She denies any other pain down here in her calves. 

EXAM

 Examination of the right knee: Tenderness over the medial portion of thenee, not the lateral aspect. There is a little bit of tenderness when she flexes her knee, and there is no valgus stressing on her leg. Normal sensation. 

RESULTS

 X-rays of the left knee shows no fractures or dislocations. 

IMPRESSION

 Right knee sprain and medial meniscus strain. 

PLAN

 At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her into an Aircast, crutches, and anti-inflammatories. All questions were answered.

 The patient will follow-up in 1 Week.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Iron deficiency anemia. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Christina Cooper is a pleasant 65-year-old female who was referred by Diane Nelson for a long-standing iron deficiencyanemia. She was diagnosed with iron deficiencyAnemia in 12/2019. Her followup blood work on 01/20/20 revealed a low hemoglobin, stable hematocrit, and normal iron labs, although ferritin was low. She had a hysterectomy in 1996. Her last colonoscopy was approximately 5 to 6 years ago. She did not have any polyps at that time. Ms. Cooper has been taking ferrous sulfate, 300 mg by mouth, and 25 mg of iron by mouth for the past year. She denies any headaches. She has been feeling fatigued often during the day, and even feverish with chills at times. When she tries to be active, she feels like she can not catch her breath and she feels as though she is wheezing. She also has been experiencing some chilling sensations. I do not know if this is related to her anxiety and depression. She states she has been sleepy afterwards. She is not taking any supplements such as iron or vitamin B12. I have asked her to continue each dose with vitamin C found in orange juice, twice daily, for the next 12 weeks. She should then reassess her blood work in about 8-12 weeks. If her bloodwork is normal, we will consider a capsule endoscopy. If this is inconclusive, we may need to consider an EDS and/or Colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. The patient does not have a pacemaker or defibrillator. She does not use oxygen at night. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 • Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills, or weight loss. Endorses fatigue. • Musculoskeletal: Endorses lower extremity tenderness. • Neurological: Endorse headaches. 

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

 • Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. • Cardiovascular: No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. No extra heart sounds. • Gastrointestinal: Tender to palpation, preferably by the middle of the abdomen. Denies hematochezia, melena, heartburn, or abdominal pain. • Integumentary: No enlarged lymph nodes. 

RESULTS

 X-ray images of the upper and lower extremities were obtained and will be reviewed in office today. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 Ms. Christina cooper is a new patient who was referral by Dianne Nelson for long- standing iron deficiency annington. Her diagnosis was made after she tried to donate blood around December 2018 and was told she was anemic. This is not the first time she hasbeen told she is anemic; however, she denies any signs of gastrointestinal bleeding. Her doctors have not told her why they think she isanemic and have not provided her with any treatment options. I has advised her to start taking her iron pills withorange juice, which she has not taken in about a year. Recheck her CBC, iron, ferritIN, B12, and folate in 8- 12 weeks, and then we can reassessher blood work. A referral was sent to her hematologist for further evaluation. She will follow up with him in 10 years.

 The patient will follow-up with me on her next visit, and I will send a referral to herhematologist. She can call us if she has any questions or worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Smith-Magenis syndrome. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Katherine Smith is a 22-month-old female, a twin, who presents to the clinic today for screening of the kidneys by ultrasound. She is a well-nourished female who is slightly fussy when examined. She has mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms. She used to only drink milk, but I took her off dairy milk and she is now drinking water. She still does not walk and she was not sitting by herself a year old. However, she is crawling and trying to take steps. She does have a speech therapist who is starting within the next couple of weeks. The patient has also seen an orthopedic and an ophthalmologist. She was told to take her off cow’s milk, which we did. She continues to drink milk but she seems to drink a lot of water. The family lives in Dallas, so her follow-up should be at the town center location. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 • Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills, or changes in appetite. Endorses weight loss. • Musculoskeletal: Endorses lower extremity hypotonia. • Neurological: endorses dyspnea on exertion. 

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

 • NeurologICAL: Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Normal hearing. • Cardiovascular: No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. • Respiratory: Normal respiratory effort. • Gastrointestinal: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. • Integumentary: Normal external female genitalia. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 Katherine Smith- Magenis Syndrome. • Medical Reasoning: The patient is a twin with this syndrome. • Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the syndrome in detail today. I explained that several organ systems can be affected by this chromosomal deletion syndrome. congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract have been reported in the literature. • Additional Testing: We are going to order a kidney ultrasound for further evaluation. • Specialist Referrals: We will send in an order for an ultrasound of the bilateral kidneys to be reviewed in office today. • Follow-up: She will follow up with me in Cheney, Wyoming. Patient Agreements: the patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

-ray of the left wrist is reviewed today and revealsevidence of aColles‘ fracture. Mild effusion about the right thumb spica. CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Right knee pain.

He notes that he has been taking ibuprofen, which has been beneficial for the pain. He also reports that he occasionally flexes his knee, which is uncomfortable. He describes that it hurts when he flexes and moves his knee; when he moves it up and down; and when he puts pressure on the medial collateral ligament. Mr. Taylor notes that it has been a week since his injury. He has not been able to participate in any physical activity for that length of time.  Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain, swelling, and effusion.

 Right knee strain, effusion, and irritation.

I have explained to him that his x-rays did not reveal any fractures or ligament abnormalities. I will get a referral to nutrition to try to help him with his diet. He will also need to lower his salt intake and modify his diet a little bit better.

 The patient will follow up with me in a couple of weeks to check on his progress.

There is no decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test. X-ray of her left knee was obtained today and reviewed. CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Low immunoglobulin A level. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Kyle Walker is a pleasant 53-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of a low immunoglobin a level. The patient was referred by his primary care physician as he has been having problems getting frequent infections. He notes that he tends to get infections in the winter time as he is so used to it. He denies any recent abdominal infections. The Patient notes that his physical was performed as part of his routine physical. He reports that he has a lot of colds and they tend to linger for a long time. He does not know if this is more than usual in theWinter time. the patient has a history of type 2 diabetes and he states that his family owns a donut shop down at the end of the street. He states that this is probably part of the cause of his diabetes. Thepatient denies ever needing a blood transfusion or blood products. He explains that he does not qualify for blood products because he has recently traveled internationally. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Musculoskeletal: Denies lower extremity pain. Neurological: Positive for fever. 

VITALS

 All vital signs are within the normal limits. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 CV: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs. RESPIRATORY: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. Neck: No lymphadenopathy, swollen lymph glands. MSK: Examination of the abdomen: Tender to palpation. function perfectly normal. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 1. Lower extremity immunodeficiency. 

PLAN

 After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. I have explained to him that his lower extremities are tender to the touch due to a deficiency in his erythema IgG1. We discussed the importance of maintaining a healthy immune system and I advised him that this deficiency is common to him and will be noted in his further labs. He was advised that it can go along with other immunodecipheral deficiencies. I also advised him to be careful with his blood products as they may cause his body to strongly react to them. The only other thing that I would say is if he does end up needing any blood products between now and when I see him next, he should make sure he tells me that he had a historyof an iga deficiency. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 The patient will follow up with me in 2 weeks to review his lab work.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Kidney stone. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Russell Russell is a pleasant 67-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right-sided pain in the right side of his abdomen below his ribs. The onset of his pain began several days ago, when he saw his primary care physician, who ordered a CT scan of the abdomen and told him that he had a kidney stone. He was sent to see a urologist for further evaluation. The CT scan revealed a 5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. There is no evidence of any rebound or guarding. No peritoneal signs. Thereis positive CVA tenderness on the right flank. The patient states that he feels like he can not find a comfortable position and that the pain is pretty bad. He reports that he has taken Tylenol, but it has not really helped. He denies any nausea, vomiting, or chills. He endorses burning with urination and peeing. He does note that his urine looks a little dark sometimes. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Constitutional: Negative for fever, chills, or vomiting. Gastrointestinal: Positive for nausea. Denies vomiting. Genitourinary: Positive CVA Tenderness. Musculoskeletal: Positive right flank tenderness. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 GI/GU: No tenderness to palpation. No evidence of rebound orguard. No Peritoneal Signs. No blood in the urine. 

ASSESSMENT

 Acute nephrolithiasis. 

PLAN

 After reviewing the patient's examination findings and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. I have explained to him that his exam findings suggest acute nephrologic nephrology or kidney stones. We discussed treatment options for this and I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively with oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. He can continue to alternate that with tylenol. I has been provided with a strainer that he can strain his urine so that we can see the stone when it passes. We will order a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and a urine culture. I will also order a urinalys and urine culture, as well as a urineculture. I want to see him again in 1 to 2 weeks. If he is still symptomatic at that time, we will discuss further treatment such as lithotripsy. We could also do a ureTERoscopy which is a small telescope small camera used to go up to the urethra and bladder and up into the ureters to retrieve the stone. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 The patient will follow up with me in 2 weeks to check on his progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Right foot ulcer. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Nicholas Reyes is a pleasant 53-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcers. The onset of his symptoms began 6 days ago, when he noticed a necrotic wound on his right foot on the pad of the foot around his heel. He initially noted a foul smell, but later noticed that his dog was also smelling his socks a lot. He noticed that the blister had become unroofed. He then noticed that there was a red streak also that was coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscle. He notes that he has been walking on the front of his foot when he is not hiking. He denies any nausea, vomiting, or chills. He reports that he had an extra blanket in his bed because he had some chills at one point. The patient initially experienced stinging and discomfort with the wound; however, he notes that the pain has improved over the last 2 days. He describes the pain as throbbing and worse with prolonged ambulation. He also reports difficulty catching his breath when he walks around the house. Mr. Reyes reports that his blood glucose levels have been trending in the 3 to 4 hundreds for the past 2 weeks. He is concerned about the redness that is moving up his leg. He endorses redness and pain in his calf that radiates up to his knee behind his kneecap. He does not appreciate any bony exposure. 

MEDICAL HISTORY

 Patient reports he is a diabetic and has diabetic neuropathy. 

SOCIAL HISTORY

 patient reports he likes to hike in the park. 

MEDICATIONS

 Patient reports taking antibiotics. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Musculoskeletal: Reports right foot Ulcer. 

VITALS

 Slight fever. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 CV: Bilateral palpable pulses femorally and popliteal pulses are present. No palpable pulses dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial. 

RESULTS

 X-ray of the right foot was reviewed today and shows no evidence of osteomyelitis. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 1. Non- hematochezia, right foot. 

PLAN

 After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. I have explained to him that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of osteopathy. We discussed treatment options for this and I have recommended that we continue his current antibiotics. He will follow up with his endocrinologist in 7 days to check his blood sugar, as well as continue to closely monitor his blood sugars. We also discussed that we will likely need to start him on a new antibiotic. I advised him that we may need to extend or change his antibiotic therapy. He was advised to continue his antibiotics therapy that his primary care physician put him on. We will order a test to check blood supply for the wound, a culture will be ordered, and we may have to look at different antibiotic therapies. Regarding his diabetes, he should continue to keep his hemoglobin A1c below 7. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 The patient will follow-up with him in7 days.
